course.subject: COMP
course.name: Exploring and Visualizing Data
course.description: This course teaches concepts and tools for exploring and visualizing data. There are a lot of real-life decision-making problems (e.g., business, logistics, economics, marketing, finance, resource management, forecasting and engineering) which can be formulated using some existing data analysis models. Existing computer science tools such as Microsoft Excel can help us to model and solve these problems easily, and to visualize the solutions.
course.exclusions: COMP 4331, ISOM 3360, RMBI 4310

reviews.author: passerby0525
reviews.title: Visualizing a good course
reviews.comment_content:
Let me put this straight, many courses deserve their hate (looking at you, phys1112), but this is definitely not one of them. Therefore, this review is to counteract the negative review, and this review might be in a slightly overly positive tone, but I promised you, this is indeed a great course.

Content:
1. Association (Apriori Approach, FP-growth Approach)
2.Clustering (k-mean, dendrogram)
3.classification (Decision Tree, Naive Bayes, NN Classifier, Neural Network, Recurrent Neural Network, SVM)
4. PCA
5. Data Warehouse
6. Web Database

Never heard of these materials? Me neither!
However, don't get discouraged by these topics that sound difficult, they are not as horrendous as they appeared to be. Most of the topics could be easily comprehended and understood after you attended the lessons (maybe with the exception of PCA, which is quite confusing for me). After you learnt about these concepts, you should be able to grasp an idea about data handling.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Raymond is a great teacher. After the lesson, he will stay to answer any confusion about the course material, and he will not end the lesson until every questions got answered. And if you have questions after the lesson, just connect him through email, he will provide in-depth and detailed answer pretty quickly.

There is a unique policy about the course, which is the existence of "coupon", which has two usages.
Firstly, it could be used to waive one question in an assignment, you would automatically obtained full points for that question whether your answers are correct or not (you can even not answer the question at all). This would come in handy when you feel struggling about a certain question, or you are rushing the assignment before the deadline and realise that you could not finish all of them on time (definitely not personal experience).
Secondly, it could help you to automatically obtain full mark in one part of the project, which would be otherwise hard if you do not use the coupon.

There are mainly two ways to obtain the coupon, which are through answering Raymond's questions during the lesson, or providing solution for the "in-class exercise" (further discussed in 'workload'). However, don't worry if you feel you could not raised hand to answer question quick enough or not smart enough to complete the "in-class" exercise. Towards the end of the semester, Raymond would start to ask students whether they have coupons or not, and if you don't, he would give you opportunities to answer his questions. Therefore, you are almost guaranteed to at least have one coupon (which is highly encouraged to be used in project).
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignment 10%
Project 20%
In-class Participation(I.e. iPRS and attendance) 10%
Mid-Term Exam 20%
Final Exam 40%

For assignment and project, they are not difficult to obtain high score as long as you are willing to put some effort, as the markings are quite lenient.
For In-class participation, erm, sleep well and don't wake up late, I guess?

For examination, there are quite a few points to be discussed.

The examination method: Raymond would allow students to vote for their desired exam method (letting us to choose the mark distribution for MC and long/short questions, ranging from 0% to 100%). For midterm, people choose 50% of MC and 50% of long/short questions, and many were disappointed with it as they feel like the MC part was difficult. As a result, the final exam consist of only long/short questions and no MC. I was in the minority side of this situation as I preferred some MCs, but hey, to each their own, and so I would just try to give some objective description about the MCs and long/short questions, and it is left for you to decide how you want your exam to be.
MC: the MC would consist of some conceptual questions, some standard question that require moderate level of calculation, and some questions that are actually compressed long question that you would need to go through like a normal long question to get the desired answer (which I think are the reason of MC being considered difficult).
Long/short questions: The long/short questions are mostly standard and straightforward questions that revolve about the taught materials, which are mostly extremely similar(or even identical) to past paper or exercises given during lessons, some questions that required proof(most are mentioned during class), and some unseen explanation question that test your understanding about the course (which are the questions that distinguish the level of students). Long/short questions would allow you to obtain at least some score as long as you write some steps, but it would be more lengthy to complete one question as you need to write a lot of words, which might cause you to have less than sufficient time to complete the whole paper.

Little tips about the exam:
1. DO THE PAST PAPER AND IN-CLASS EXERCISE! This is the utmost important tip. There are many similar questions between the past paper/in-class exercise and the actually exam paper, so as long as you complete those things and memorize how to do them, you should be fine.
2. Remember the proof. There are few proofs about the materials that Raymond would bring up during the lessons, remember to copy and remember them as there is always a proof question in the exam.
3. Try to make some programs to help you do the calculation. (This tip might not be applicable next time this course is offered as I don't know whether the exam will still be carried out online). The exam would almost always required many calculations for some questions, which would be impossible for people to finish manually within the time limit. Therefore, you should make some programs that help you do those tedious calculations. Don't worry if you do not have any programming background, Excel could do the same computations after you put formula into the cells.

The grade (total, mean, sd)
Midterm: (100, 61.41, 15.02)
Final exam:(200, 117.42, 38.46)
Assignments have mean ~90/100 and project has mean ~95/100
I got +1.3sd for midterm and +1.0sd for final, and got an A.
But before you boo me and call me biased, may I mentioned that there are reports of people that got mean in final yield an B+, and people that get -0.5sd for final yield an B. So I think it is not a lie that the course has good grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is not that heavy, for the whole semester, there are only 2 homework and a project.

HW: for the homework, there will be one before the midterm exam and one after the midterm exam, which test your knowledge about the course materials, each of them consist of four to five questions. For a slow learner like me, I can complete it within about five hours, i.e. one hour for each question (but you need to take consideration that I often missed the lessons and would just learn the material when I do the homework), which is relatively small workload when compared to its deadline (about two months each).

Project: Most workload of the course comes from the project. The project could be done in group of two or one(i.e. only yourself). The project consist of three phases, which as long as you follow Raymond's guidance, would be very easy to obtained full score. As a matter of fact, the mean of the project is more than 90%. For the whole project, as a one man group, I worked about three days, which again might seem much, but is actually quite light given the lenient deadline.

In-class exercise(Optional): In-class exercises are given by Raymond during a lesson, which would be discussed in the next lesson. If you are confident, for the next lesson, you could arrive the class a bit earlier and show your answer to Raymond, if it is correct, you could obtain a "coupon". However, this is totally optional and I personally never did the In-class exercise before revisions for the exams.

Special mention: attendance. Although the course should returned to face-to-face next semester, I think this semester attendance record system are still worth to mention. Your attendance will be recorded if you upload a screenshot of the lesson after the class. Also, during the lesson, there will be some iPRS questions that would grant you mark as long as you answer them (regardless of whether your answer is correct).

reviews.author: khwan
reviews.title: Basically a data mining intro course.
reviews.comment_content:
Contents:
- Association Mining
- Clustering
- Decision Trees
- Naive Bayesian Filter and Bayesian Networks
- KNN, basic neural network
- Some measurement on the classification performance.
- PCA
- OLAP / Data warehouse
- Web Database
Most of the concepts taught in the course are definitely helpful in data analysis. Definitely a good course to learning Quantitative reasoning(QR).
But remember, this is an introductory course. Some of the explanations in advanced topics may not be well explained. If you want to know more, you should take the data mining course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Raymond explains concepts clearly and logically so that students in other disciplines will also understand. He will also spend time talking about some of the rationales behind some data mining techniques.
Occasionally he may spend extended duration on some of the concepts which are already taught in previous lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignment 10%
Project 20%
In-class Participation 10% (IPRS)
Mid-Term Exam 20%
Final Exam 40%

midterm above 1.5sd,
for final exam around the mean(around 60%), got B+.
There are Rumors about the A-range being narrowed. If you want to take the course just because of a good grade, think twice.
reviews.comment_workload:
I would say the workload is reasonable.
There are 2 assignments. Each assignment has around 1 month to do it.
There is 1 project which has 3 phases spread across the semester. During the project, students will analyze real-world data using XLMiner with specific technique learned in lectures.

For the midterm and final exams, you are allowed to bring cheatsheets. Remember to print every important concept taught in the lectures, and play around XLMiner, as those will be tested.

reviews.author: Mango Pudding
reviews.title: Data mining for beginners; Could be an alternative to COMP1021 if you really hate coding
reviews.comment_content:
This course Uses XLMiner in Excel, NO PROGRAMMING is required.

= Topics overview =
1. Association rule mining
- Finding frequent patterns and association rules
- Apriori algorithm
- FP-Growth algorithm
2. Clustering
- Grouping things together
- K-means clustering
- Hierarchical and divisive clustering
3. Classification
- Predicting using a decision tree constructed based on historical records
- Decision trees (ID3, C4.5, CART)
- Bayesian classifier (Naive Bayes, Bayesian belief network)
> The project revolves around this topic
> IMO the hardest to understand is the Bayesian belief network, which is taught out of order just before finals
4. Dimension reduction
- e.g. 2D data representation into a 1D data representation
- PCA Principal component analysis
5. Data warehouse
- What pre-computed results to store in the DW to reduce response time
- Greedy algorithm for which view to materialise
6. Web databases
- Ranking webpages
- HITS algorithm
- PageRank algorithm
> Requires very basic matrix knowledge, which they will teach as tutorial content

= Opinions =
If you really hate coding in COMP1021 and can put up with manually going through algorithms, this course could be an alternative to fulfil QR common core.

Interesting subject to learn even without prior knowledge, and you'll learn how powerful data really is and why companies crave them.

Quite a portion of the course is manually running through algorithms, which may get tedious with many steps, especially during the exam. Even though this course doesn't expect any programming, I ended up spending more time coding some of the algorithms that print every step in detail, and some of which required way more advanced python packages than COMP1021. Was coding them that worth it? Sort of. It acted as a tool in reinforcing the content and saved a bit of my sanity, yet wasn't a significant advantage for exams.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Do not worry if you know nothing about the course, because I didn't either beforehand. Explains everything very clearly and in detail, and repeats until the concept is understood. Would answer out-of-scope questions after class if the student is interested. His English is a bit broken but is legible.

As for the seemingly long PowerPoint slides, need not fear. Most of them are just step-by-step screenshots of using XLMiner.

Very efficient TA team, releasing results within days of submitting assignments and even exams.

Tutorials are (mostly) optional, and they would notify you about the topic of the upcoming tutorial session via email so that you could choose to attend or not. If you couldn't fully grasp the content in the lecture, tutorials are helpful.

Some of the tutorials will teach content that is assessed in the exams but not taught in lectures. They will explicitly note which ones are particularly important.
reviews.comment_grading:
*Online semester, special arrangements may be applied*

Assignment 10% (5% each)
Project 20%
In-class participation 10% (iPRS participation 5%, Camera turned on 5%)
Midterm 20%
Final 40%

= Coupon system =
Raise up your hand to answer select questions or show your solution to in-class exercises, you'll get a coupon, very easy to get.

Coupons can be used to waive one question in an assignment and get full marks for that question or used to get full marks for the output files in project phase 3 (which usually isn't easy without coupons).

Make sure to have THREE coupons for the entire course, which they pretty much guarantee you to have since there are so many opportunities to get one, and even create trivial in-class activities for those who haven't got any.

= Exam format =
They let you vote on:
- The proportions of MC and LQ (e.g. 20% MC 80% LQ)
- The length of the exam
- The proportion of question difficulty (e.g. 80% straightforward 20% not-straightforward but easy)
- Bonus question or not (+10%)

= Stats =
Assignments and the project have the means at 90+% of the max score, so you essentially need to get full marks for a good grade.

Midterm:
- Min Max 9.5 & 100
- Mean 54.32 / 100
- SD 17.87
- "Effective" score due to the tightness of the online exam +20

Final:
- Min Max (Before re-mark) 21 & 190
- Mean 108.33 / 200
- SD (Before re-mark) 34.81
- "Effective" score +40

I got full marks for all assignments and project phases, midterm ~+0.43 SD, final ~+0.77 SD, and got A- in the end.
reviews.comment_workload:
*Online semester, special arrangements may be applied*

= Assignments =
One for each half of the semester, on content before and after the midterm. They encourage you to complete the relevant questions right after they've taught them, so the workload is spread out evenly.

= Project =
Group of 1-2 members, freely formed.
Spans the entire semester, but most of the work is concentrated in the last month (Phase 2 and 3).

Phase 1: Excel
Simply convert their text files containing the training and test data into one Excel file, one is expected to get full marks on this. Be careful to match their specifications EXACTLY including case sensitivity.

Phase 2: Design report
Try many different classification model setups, and pick 5 to put into the design report.
The most exhausting part is the step-by-step screenshots on how to use XLMiner for pre-processing and each classification model.

Phase 3: Final report and output files
One week immediately after the submission of phase 2.
Adding to the phase 2 report, with the results of each classification model and two examples manually demonstrating how the model predicts.

reviews.author: windT.T
reviews.title: Kind prof, Good content, messy ppt
reviews.comment_content:
Definitely an intro data mining course.
Since this is a common core course, it emphasizes on the computation instead of the proofs/ correctness of algorithms. However, there are some proofs that you have to remember (which Prof Wong will write on the whiteboard instead of the ppt). So, do attend his classes!
Although some involve abstract and complex concepts, these are usually an introduction and Prof Wong will explain them well. So again, make sure you are attentive in order not to get lost easily.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Wong's is definitely one of the best professors in the CSE department. He is
In addition, he responses to emails really quickly, I remembered that I need more clarifications of concepts, and he responded in minutes, with a detailed paragraph!
Also, he is very kind, so don't hestitate to ask questions, even you think it is a stupid one.
reviews.comment_grading:
Final Exam 40%
Mid Term Exam 20%
Assignment (x2) 10%
IPRS Questions (attendance) 10%
Project 20%

The grading is fair since I think the B range is very wide (I have friends that are below mean or slightly higher than mean, both got B-range). However, I will say that A range is rather difficult to get.

My scores:
Assignment and Project: Full
Mid Term Exam: +0.5 SD
Final Exam: +1.1 SD
Grade: A-
reviews.comment_workload:
I think the workload is rather small, given you are not a deadline fighter. Definitely, you will need some time to elaborate on the main concepts introduced in the slides, since I think the PowerPoint slides are rather messy. Definitely make an effective summary when you review a chapter so you won't get messed easily when preparing for the exam. Since I believe the course content is similar every semester, do check the past papers and have a try.

For the assignment, they are EXTREMELY similar to the past assignments, so if you have sources, definitely take a look before submitting in order to gain full marks. However, I encourage you not to directly copy since the assignments are meant to be practices of the course materials, which are useful to consolidate the concepts.

For the project, there are three phrases, if you follow the deadlines and guidelines by Prof Wong strictly, you will be fine and get full marks.

reviews.author: csisgood
reviews.title: Overrated..at least in this semester
reviews.comment_content:
This course mainly focus on the things of data mining. The following topics are included.
1. Association Rules
2. Clustering (Partition and Hierarchical)
3. Bayes Classifier
4. Bayes Network
5. KNN
6. Basic Neural Network
7. PCA
8. OLAP
9. Web DB

I think this course emphasis too much on calculation without any derivation and only a little concepts. Don't expect to learn too much in this course.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is OK. At least clear but his lecture notes are extremely messy and bad.
reviews.comment_grading:
Some one told me that getting 0.5SD higher in final and midterm with full marks in assignments in this course will surely get at least A-.

However, I think starting from this semester the grading scheme has changed. A little bit worse than before. At least I get, 0.5SD higher in both final and midterm and full marks in assignments still get an B+.

However, as a CS students, I could say the grading of this course is the best in CSE department. For most of the CSE course, getting 1SD higher still getting B or something. Because of this point, I will give this course B in grading.
reviews.comment_workload: Very Low Workload. As describe in other comments

reviews.author: Tommy Li
reviews.title: An overrated course
reviews.comment_content:
Don't get confused by the course title, it's just "Introduction to Data Mining". Topics include:

1. Association
2. Clustering
3. Classification
4. Data Warehouse
5. Dimension Reduction
6. Web Databases

This course focuses on the steps to do the actual data mining, but not the concept behind. In this course, you will be trained to be a machine for processing some data. Don't expect that you will be able to do something cool after this course. You will only learn how to do some specific data processing steps for an extremely specific and simplified scenario.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Raymond explained the data mining process clearly in a step-by-step manner. He assumed we have no prior knowledge, know nothing about high school maths, know nothing about computer science. He spent way too much time to elaborate some of the details which may make you feel boring.

But still, I am quite impressed his ability to explain complicated concepts. The content is as easy as ABC after he has explained it.  I should quote from Prof. Leung from PHYS 1112, "You have learnt it in kindergarten."
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is not as good as the previous offering. You need to work much harder than before to get an A+ in the course. It is heard that the mean only gets you a B in this semester compared to B+ in the previous ones.

The exam difficulty has increased a lot, you have to complete the question quite quickly in order to finish all. The final question involve solving a system of linear equations (instead of simple arithmetic in previous semesters). I am bad with those maths and made careless mistakes in calculation costing me 10 points in final. And also another 6 point because not finishing the clustering in time due to that equation solving. It seems the paper test your maths and time management skills instead of your knowledge about the topics.

HW: 10/10
Project: 20/20
IPRS: 10/10
Midterm: 93.75/100 (Mean: 65.76/100, SD: 15.88) => 18.75/20
Final: 175/200 (Mean: 125.33/200, SD: 30.03) => 35/40
Overall Grade: A

+1.7 sd in both midterm and final still yields an A. I don't think that can be classified as a good grade course, right?

EDIT: Please don't get me wrong. To be fair, this is not a bad grade course, and there are much more courses with grading worse than that. Based on past experience and other reviews (in previous offerings of this course and other courses), +1.0~1.2 sd should at least yield an A-, +1.3~1.5 sd should at least yield an A, and +1.6~1.7 sd should at least yield an A+ for a course with better grading. What I really meant is the grading scheme is not as good as before, and it is still reasonable in some sense.
reviews.comment_workload:
HW are easy. Just copy the HWs in the previous offering. They are mostly the same.

Project is easy but a little bit time-consuming. You have to capture screenshots for ALL steps of building your classification model so the TA can follow exactly what you performed.

For exam preparation, doing 4 years of past paper should be sufficient for getting a decent grade. Most questions come from past exam, DO copy them in your cheatsheet or you probably will regret.

reviews.author: Andy K
reviews.title: Introduction to data visualization
reviews.comment_content:
The course introduces a lot of basic model of data analysis. Teach you how to use XLMiner
1. association rule
2.  k-mean clustering
3. dendrogram clustering
4. decision tree
5. Bayes classification
6. k-NN classification
7. neural network
8. PCA
9. data warehouse
10. web ranking
...

Good intro course
reviews.comment_teaching: Raymond is a very nice professor! He always sends the email during midnight and replies your email patiently. He explained things in very details so sometimes the class was a little bit boring. But I highly recommend you to listen his class not only because it has iPRS questions, but also the slides are hard to fully understand by yourself.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grade is not that good actually. Because the content is very easy, the mean of every task is pretty high. And it will be very dangerous for you to make some careless mistakes.

Assignment 10%
Project 20%
In-class Participation 10%
Mid-Term Exam 20%
Final Exam 40%

My midterm is 71/100 (around mean), and around 90% in all projects and homework. Though my final is 200/200 (mean: 155), I can only get an A. I guess quite a few people get the full mark in the final exam since it's very easy.
reviews.comment_workload:
Very light workload. For each project phase, you only need several hours to finish.

Remember to have a look at the past paper, 50% of the questions will repeat in the final.

reviews.author: HIHIYO
reviews.comment_content:
It is about basic concept of different data mining tools:
K mean clustering
KNN clustering
Neurual network
Dicision tree
.......
reviews.comment_teaching: Raymond's lecture is fun. Each lecture will has 2 to 3 IPRS questions. You have to answer total 20 IPRS to obtain the full participation score. But dont worry, he gives more than enough PRS quedtion to us. It has lecture vedio for each lesson. You can answer question in the lectute to obtain a coupon, and it can be used to waive one homework question or phase 3 project output.

My score

reviews.author: takecare
reviews.title: A brief introduction to data mining, machine learning, web database and search engine
reviews.comment_content:
1. Association rule mining (confidence, lift ratio)

2. Apriori algorithm

3. FP-Growth algorithm

4. sequential/forgetful k-means clustering

5. Hierarchical clustering I (Dendrogram, agglomerative approach)

6. Hierarchical clustering II divisive approach (polythetic/monothetic chi-square)

7 Decision Tree classifier(ID3, C4.5, Gini)

8. Performance metrics I (Confusion matrix, Error report, lift chart, decile-wise lift chart)

9. Bayesian classifier
(Naive Bayes, Bayesian Belief Network)

10. Nearest Neighbor / kNN Classifier

11. Neural Network & Multilayer Perceptron

12. Performance II
(Recall, precision, accuracy, specificity, validation and test set)

13. Principal component analysis (PCA)

14. Data Warehouse

15. Web Database

It is fruitful enough for newbies to know what is going on in data analysis.

Content may vary slightly, depending on whether Raymond will have enough time to teach support vector machine (SVM). In this term, he did not have time to cover it so it is omitted.

If you just want to take machine learning course (COMP4211) in HKUST rather than elsewhere (online or during exchange), you are better to enroll in this class for your sake to have a bigger picture. It is because details like kNN/Naive Bayes classifier, hierarchical and k-means clustering may not be covered in the other.
reviews.comment_teaching: Raymond is one of the most helpful professors in the CSE department. He responds to email questions in detail and gives explanations which are always understandable.
reviews.comment_grading:
Participation (iPRS) 10%
Homework (@2, each 5%)10%
Project (3 phases) 20%
Midterm exam 20%
Final exam 40%

No much difficulty if you remember all examples demonstrated in class (with lecture video review). Getting exam score above SD is just a piece of cake if you have 'source' because almost 80% of exam questions are directly copied and pasted from past exam papers (e.g. most exam questions in Spring 2017 are from those in Spring 2015 but not Spring 2016, so be careful of this pattern :P), homework and examples demonstrated in the class. Also, cheat sheet is allowed in midterm and final exam.

If you are into data analytics but you have little knowledge, this course definitely gives you better taste of it with good experience and nice grade.
reviews.comment_workload: All assignments (homework and project) are easy and straightforward. Getting full score of homework is just a piece of cake if you have 'source'.

reviews.author: LoYuk
reviews.title: hea讀個grade都唔會差

Association rules
clustering

bayes rule

雖然望落好𩁘，但由於係Raymond教導至成個course變得非常簡單，完全一步一步guide住做，下一堂又會review番上一堂學過既野。有埋手寫notes，就算完全無上過堂，望下份notes跟住做assignment都唔會錯。但係如果你之前有學過少少data mining/stat既話都會有少少悶。最後講多句，Raymond世一。

Group Project 可以一個人做，二個人都得，都係用下excel 整幾個model。小弟就自己一個，上堂個陣會講晒有乜要做，跟住寫落去就得，唔明可以問Raymond或者睇番recordings。

Mid Term 如果有上過堂，臨入去之前望兩眼notes就得，可以做埋份sample paper，mt/exam 入面都會見到相似既題目。

mt/final 就高0.5 SD
最後turn out B+

每份asm仲有得waive一題，
成個course可以當免費賺左3個credits。
係個project 要一篇文出黎，但係Raymond 已經提早俾大家做，只要你之前整好5個model，篇文最尾一日都可以寫到出黎

reviews.author: 星詠狗狗
reviews.title: Nice professor, great teaching
reviews.comment_content:
Topics:
1. Association
2. Clustering
3. Classification
4. PCA
5. Data Warehouse
6. Web DB
7. Graph (Newly added this year)

As this is a common core course, it only teaches basic concepts of the topic. Those are easy to understand, you can enroll for high-level courses if you are interested in deeper knowledge.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Raymond is a great teacher. He could explain the content well in layman's language. The class is interactive due to the existence of "Coupon" (Will be further mentioned later). And he will stay after class to answer students' questions. Even if you do not have any questions, you can still stay after class and chat with him. Also, he will reply to your email quickly if you have any questions.

You can vote for the details of the midterm and final exams (e.g. Proportion of Multiple choice and long questions, Allowance of cheat sheet, bonus question)

In this course, you can obtain a "Coupon" by answering questions in class. Raymond will ask many questions in class, and most of them are very easy. Using "coupon", you can waive a question in an assignment (at most one for each assignment), or use it to get full marks in the predicted attribute files in project phase 3. So getting three coupons is recommended. At least getting one as it is impossible to get full mark in phase 3 without using coupon.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading Scheme:
 Assignment 10%
 Project 20%
 In-class Participation 10%
 Mid-Term Exam 20%
 Final Exam 40%

Project Grading Policy:
 Phase 1
    Excel file (10%) (via Canvas (softcopy))
 Phase 2
    Design Report (30%) (in class (hardcopy))
 Phase 3
    Final Report (40%) (in class (hardcopy))
    Predicted Attribute Files for the Second Real Dataset (20%) (via Canvas (softcopy))

It is easy to get full or nearly full marks in assignments and projects, you can get the mark in projects if you meet the requirements. The in-class participation can be got by doing IPRS questions, it does not matter if you answer them correctly or not. It is just an alternative form of attendance.
Midterm and final exams are not hard if you could spend about a day writing a good cheat sheet and do one to two past papers.

Light workload, you can choose to form a 2 people group for the project or do it on your own. Even if you choose to do the project independently, it can be done within a day.

This might be helpful if you were having trouble with a particular question or racing to finish the project before the due date and realized you couldn't do it all (definitely not personal experience).

reviews.author: OuO
reviews.title: High-quality course with a high-quality teaching team and grading scheme
reviews.comment_content:
The content is fine. It includes many basic concepts of data mining and some basic logic of Artificial Intelligence. In addition, this course is way more useful than COMP1021 because you will get familiar with the algorithms of Computer Science.

There are 6 Major Topics in this course:
1. Association
2. Clustering
3. Classification
4. Data Warehouse
5. Dimension Reduction
6. Web Databases

Lecture Class Content:
Before Mid Term:
01. Overview
02. Rule Concept
03. Project
04. How to Activate XLMiner
05. How to Use XLMiner Outside CSE Lab
06. Rule Tool (with excel)
07. Cluster kMean (with excel)
08. Cluster Dendrogram
09. Classification Decision Tree Concept Tool (with excel)
10. Classification Naive Bayes (with excel)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
After Mid Term:
10. Classification Naive Bayes (with excel)
11. Classification NNClassifier (with excel)
12. Neural Network (with excel)
13. Recurrent Neural Network
14. SVM
15. Classification Concept
16. PCA
17. Data Warehouse
18. WebDB

Tutorial Class Content:
01. File Scanning and PDF File Merging
02. Possible XLMiner Installation Issues and Solutions
03. Association
04. FP Tree
05. Using XLMiner for Association Rule Mining and k-Means Clustering (with excel)
06. Fundamental Matrix Operation
07. Using XLMiner for Hierarchical Clustering (with excel)
08. Using XLMiner for Classification (Decision Tree)
09. /
10. Using XLMiner for Classification (Naive Bayes Classifier, Nearest Neighbor Classifier) (with excel)
11. Using XLMiner for Classification (Neural Network) (with excel)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Explanation of concepts:
To be honest, the lecture notes were a bit messy, but Raymond explained the concepts very clearly by using Zoom annotation and Microsoft Whiteboard. He used in-class exercises to ensure that we understood what he taught.

The speed of replying email:
The speed of reply always shocks me because Raymond replies to emails insanely quickly. One of the experiences is that he replied to my email within 10 minutes after I had sent it to him and the content of his email was longer than I expected.

Accent:
Raymond has a bit heavy Cantonese accent, but it is acceptable generally because he repeated the content and concepts quite many times.

TA Team:
It is worth praising all the TAs in this course because they were efficient, which I did not expect. They replied to emails quickly and released the scores of assessments (including mid term and final exam) within 48 hours.

Freedom/Flexibility of mid term and final exam:
We could vote on the format of Mid Term and Final Exam, such as the length, difficulty, and bonus-questions-or-not of exams.

By the way, I think Raymond (Prof. Wong) may be one of the best professors/lecturers in UST because he really spends time on teaching and taking care of students inside and outside of the learning aspect.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignment 10% (2 Assignments)
Project 20%
- Phase 1 (2%)
- Phase 2 (6%)
- Phase 3 (12%)
In-class Participation 10%
- iPRS Questions (5%)
- Camera On (5%)
Mid-Term Exam 20%
Final Exam 40%

There is a special coupon system in this course. You will obtain a coupon if you can answer the question correctly. Honestly, it is very easy to get the coupon because there are a countless questions for you to answer.

Remember to obtain 3 coupons in this course because you can waive one of the questions in each assignment. Also, you can use a coupon to waive a part of phase 3 of the project, which is very helpful. You will regret it if you do not obtain any coupons.

There were extremely long midterm and final exam because he wanted to avoid cheating as much as he could.

Assignment 2: Average = 92.62/100
Project Phase 1: Average = 96.89/100

Final Exam: Average = 109.58/200 with SD = 34.81/200

By the way, this course may be one of the most lenient courses in UST because I was -0.63SD in mid term and -0.85SD in final exam, but I still got a B in this course.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Raymond is a good lecturer to explain the things very well. He will show you the algorithms step by step and explain it to the students so that I think it should be no problem for most of students to understand the contents in lecture even you don't have any computer science background.

Raymond welcome students to ask question freely during the lecture. If you have questions just raise hand and ask him. He is willing to answer all kinds of questions.

During the lecture, Raymond will give "coupon" to those who have answered his questions. 1 Coupon can be used to waive 1 question from a homework to get full mark. Also, it can be used to waive the prediction result part in the project, which means you can directly get full score even your prediction result in the project is a crap (or you can even not hand in the prediction text file :D).

Don't worry that you cannot get a coupon from Raymond lecture as he will ask many questions during the lecture time and most of them are very easy even primary students can answer them. So don't be afraid of it. Besides, Raymond will send email to ask those students who have no coupon to register and let them answer the questions sometimes.  You can take the chance of this to get a coupon for your project if your hand speed is not as fast as other students in the class.

Raymond powerpoint usually consist of many slides to show you how to use XLMiner step by step. But I think many of them are actually redundant and can be simplified. So don't be scared by a vast amount of powerpoint slides, most of them are just XLMiner demonstration part :D
reviews.comment_grading:
Don't know the detail cutoff, but seems quite lenient generally.

Grading Scheme:
10% Participation (Requires screenshot in lecture iPRS and answering the iPRS)
10% Homework (Easy, but the wording is quite long)
20% Project (Easy, separated in 3 phase, Raymond will teach you how to finish them and you can just simply follow his given format to get full marks here)
20% Midterm
40% Final

This semester midterm consists of 50% MC and 50% LQ, which is quite challenging

For the final exam, it is 100% LQ.

Both exams are in tight-time schedule, open-book and open to online materials. It is recommended to use some program or excel(?) to help you solving the question. Otherwise it is quite impossible to finish the whole paper in the final exam.

You can expects the participation, homework and project mean is around 90-95%. So the things determine your grade is midterm and final.

Getting +1.3 sd from midterm and +1.5 sd from final giving me an A+, which is not very useful for general grading. You can refer to other review to know more about the grading. I believed that the grading is generally good.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is mainly come from the exam, homework and project.

There are 2 homeworks in this semester, each of them gives you nearly 1 month to finish (maybe?). You are definitely having enough time to finish it on time. The questions are not difficult, but require repetitive calculation and long steps, which may cause you to have careless mistakes. Be careful of it.

The project is not difficult also. You can form 1-2 people in a group to finish it.
Phase 1 is handing in a Excel file which is adding the column names to the data in txt tile originally. You can finish it within 10 minutes.
Phase 2 is handing in the design report. You need to give 5 models to do your prediction. For each of the model, you need to clearly write down the parameters and steps so that TA can follow what are you doing exactly. It is not difficult but may cost you some time because you need to do many screenshot D:
Phase 3 is the final report. You just need to add the results from each of your model in phase 2 and write down the conclusions. Again it is not difficult. Generally I just copy and paste the results of my model and change some wording to finish this part.

It is easy and your report just follow the format given by Raymond then it is okay. You don't need to consider the design and formatting of the report.

reviews.author: garbage
reviews.title: A very good professor with hellish exams.
reviews.comment_content: A little of everything. If you have not learn algorithm, matrix, or database before, this would be a very good ccc because after this course, you would be able to understand what the analysts are talking about instead of being in the middle of nowhere.
reviews.comment_teaching: Very detailed teaching. Very VERY responsible. Feel free to ask Raymond any questions because he would definitely reply very quickly. Also, he and the TAs only used about 12 hours to correct the midterm exam papers and uploaded the scores.
reviews.comment_grading:
The exams are as HELL. If you are going to take this course in the future, do check the exam papers of 2020 Spring because you would find that it is much MUCH harder than the previous ones and contains MUCH MORE questions. The exams are designed in this way so that the students would not be able to finish the questions in time (even if you are genius because the process of calculating would definitely take up most of your time) in order to prevent the students from cheating. Raymond admitted that he himself cannot finish the exam in the given period of time LOLL.
Mean for the midterm: 47/100
SD for the midterm: 14
Mean for the final: 90.7/200
SD for the final: 25
I personally got 60 for mid-term and 129.75 for final and yield an A. Good grade!
reviews.comment_workload: One project. 2 homeworks. Would take up about half a day to do the project if you have decided to form a project group of yourself. The homeworks are not hard but be careful because most of the people would get full marks. Overall there is not much workload. Also, preparing for the exams are very trivial compared with good strategies while taking the exams. :)

reviews.comment_grading:
The mid-term exam is at a moderate level, but the final exam is extremely hard. Instead of just copying the questions from the past few years (he did this in previous years), the final exam paper had many new questions and some of them include hard concepts.

Professor Wong may distribute coupons to the students answering questions in class. The coupon can guarantee students with a full mark in one question in homework or one phase of the project. The coupon system can effectively help to lower the workload.

reviews.author: wufung
reviews.title: Best CC I've ever seen
reviews.comment_content:
The is a fruitful common core.
As an introduction course to data mining, it tells you basic concepts of different data mining and machine learning techniques, like Decision Tree, Clustering, Bayesian Network, Neural Network, PCA, and SVM. It only needs some simple calculation, except some matrix concepts for PCA (Raymond and tutors will teach you though).
reviews.comment_teaching:
Raymond is funny throughout the class. You will never know he is a CPEG head if you do not search about him.
He teaches well. He shows the workout step-by-step in his slides and on the board. Though, it is quite boring, sometimes for some basic concepts.
He distributes coupon to the one who asks, answers questions, or writing the answers to the exercises onto the board. Taking 3 coupons is enough for the whole course.
He is democratic that everyone attends that session has the right to vote the examination format(MC / SQ / LQ / Bonus Question), number of questions, and cheat sheet.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignment 10%
Project 20%
In-class Participation 10%
Mid-Term Exam 20%
Final Exam 40%

2 assignments and 3-part project throughout the course.
Each assignment has 5 questions. The project is not too hard to deal with. Coupons could be used to waive 1 question of each assignment and the last part of the project.

Attendance is taken by answering PRS questions. 0.5% attendance score for each question. Raymond will ask 1~3 questions per class.

You could get full marks easily for assignments and project. And with full attendance score, +1.0SD in both midterm and exam, then you will get an A in this course.
reviews.comment_workload:
Not too heavy workload. Not so much thing to do. You only have to spend a few hours before the submission to deal with the 2 assignments and the project.
It has a tutorial but no need to attend unless you do not get the ideas. It will teach you how to use the software XLMiner and calculate Matrix. But Raymond will also introduce it in class.

reviews.author: Roland Xu
reviews.comment_content:
The  content of this course turns out to be very useful and applicable.
1. Association (Apriori Approach, FP-growth Approach)
2.Clustering (k-mean, dendrogram)
3.classification (Decision Tree, Naive Bayes, NN Classifier, Neural Network, Recurrent Neural Network, SVM)
4. PCA
5. Data Warehouse
6. Web Database
Some of them seem very abstract but the professor will illustrate them with pretty straightforward examples and graph.
The part that is most interested and useful for me is probably Bayes Network. It helps me a lot when I learned Al-related probability in later part.
The statistic method used for classification (Decision Tree, Naive Bayes, etc.) in this course provided an easy way to do simple classification.
However, I have to say some of the content is somehow boring, distracting me somehow when I trying to focus on the course material.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Raymond Wong is a nice and patient professor.
He will illustrate some abstract point with example and graphs. He will also give Q&A time after each class.
His English accent is acceptable.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is quite good compared with other COMP course.
I will list my grade and my friend's for reference
My:
Middle: around mean
Final: above 1 sd
HW: nearly full
Project: nearly full
Total: overall 81+, Letter Grade is A-

My friend's
Middle: 1 sd
Final: 1 sd
HW: nearly full
Project: nearly full
Total: overall 83+, Letter Grade is A
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is pretty low!
One or two hours each week for reviewing, hw, and project is quite enough.
There are 3 hw in total, and there is 1 month for you to complete each of them.
There are 3 phases for project; first 2 spent you at most 3 hours in total, and the last 1 might take you more.

reviews.author: Dreamcatcher
reviews.comment_content:
1. Association
2. Clustering
3. Classification
4. Data Warehouse
5. Dimension Reduction
6. Web Databases

It was the first time for me to get to know more about data visualization in a course. The topics are interesting and managable. You get to know more how to analyze data using XLMiner or even calculating the datas manually.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Raymond is a really good teacher. He is passionate and always patiently explains every concept again and again. In addition, he often searches for different ways to elaborate the concept, which made me understand the concept better and memorize easily.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignment 10%
Project 20%
In-class Participation 10%
Mid-Term Exam 20%
Final Exam 40%

For assignment:
The questions are similar to the questions professor showed in class. If you are familiar with the content in class, you are able to manage the assignment. If you still cannot do the questions by yourself, you can also refer to the slides uploaded in the class website. (The slides show step-by-step guide for how to solve a problem.)

For project:
My partner and I spent half a day dealing with it. It is not very hard, but you have to spend some time to transfer or reduce the data.


For in-class participation:
You have to answer in total 20 iPRS questions (whether answering wrong or right does not matter.)

Overall:
The scores of assignment, project, and the participation are not that hard to get, so most of the students can get very high score in these parts. Therefore, I think the midterm and final actually decide your grade.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is okay. There are 2 assignments (one before midterm, and another before final). There are also a project (it is seperated to 3 phases. It seems quite a lot to do in the semester, however, those assignments and project actually make you understand and practice more about the concept. Additionally, the questions occurring in the assignments are quite similar to those in midterm and final. Moreover, you can actually get good scores in assignments and project quite easily if you are willing to work on and complete them.

reviews.author: YCL2018
reviews.title: No Coding... Just Math
reviews.comment_content:
Since everyone else wrote about what the course content includes, I won't dive into it cause its unlikely to change for the next decade to come. The course content is quite interesting in some ways and allows students with no computer science background to understand and possibly be able to communicate (if you understand the course) with others on data mining. There is no coding or any sort of understanding of it for this course.
On another note, some of the content of this course could really be used in real life or at least understand parts about the real life. For example, one of the data mining methods (Principal Component Analysis) requires the calculation of the Eigenvalues which basically allowed me to say "Ayyy.. I know that" when I was watching Avengers Endgame.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Raymond is a very passionate professor and has really cared for the students' success in his course. While he obviously can't give every student an A+, he has provided as much support as he could to help students understand the course and gain extra credit. The way to gain extra credits was so easy it would be stupid not to go for it.
Even though the professor's teaching was very good, his teaching assistants were as passionate nor cared about the students as much. They basically read off the powerpoint and made no efforts in making the tutorials more interesting. So I don't really see a point of going to the tutorials since you can just read the tutorial notes yourself.
reviews.comment_grading:
I think the grading was quite fair and allowed students who aren't super good at test taking to balance their grades out with the group project and the assignments.
In some aspects, the assessments given could be way harder than the content taught in class but as long as you do the past papers, it is unlikely that you will score low in the exams.
Do keep in mind that there are computer science major students in the course. And for a student without any knowledge in the area, it could be intimidating to see someone code in the lecture theatre. But don't worry, you aren't competing with those guys, there is no way you can beat them with the same effort they put in the course.
reviews.comment_workload:
The assignment workload could get a bit much if you don't properly organize your time throughout the semester especially if you don't understand the course content very well.
The project workload is pretty chill, you basically just follow the steps given and you will score a 100% no problem. So for most time, relax and organize your time to finish the work. Professor Raymond normally sends out reminders letting the students know the different milestones in class thus allowing students to do the assignment questions right after the lecture while the knowledge is still fresh.

reviews.author: 科大CS(ChiSin)佬
reviews.title: Easy course and good grading (although harder to get good grade than the past, still a good grading course)
reviews.comment_content:
An introduction course for datamining
1. association rule
2. clustering (k-mean and hierarchical clustering)
3. classification
    3.1 decision tree
    3.2 naiveBayes
    3.3 Nearest neighbor classifier
    3.4 neural network
    3.5 classification concept
4. data warehouse
5. dimension reduction (PCA)
6. web database

If you have studied about matrix and statistic before, you will have benefit when understand some concept in the course. But it is still not difficult for student who has no mathematics background about matrix and statistic.
For midterm and final exam, prof. raymond wong will ask us to vote for the arrangement for the exam, we can choose to have cheatsheet or not, how many % of MC question, long question and short question, and have bonus question or not.
reviews.comment_teaching:
his teaching is very slow but he can explain the concept very clear.
You can obtain a 'coupon' if you ask a question or answer his question in the lecture, the coupon can be used to waive a question in homework.
reviews.comment_grading:
As a COMP course, this course has a good grading.
Very easy to get B range but you have to work hard to get A range (actually make sense)
Assignment 10% (total 2 homework this semester)
Project 20% (1 project, divided to 3 phase)
In-class Participation 10% (using PRS)
Mid-term exam 20%
Final exam 40%

For me, I get
full mark for both homework,
overall 98.4/100 for project,
full mark for participation,
74/100 for midterm (mean = 65.76, sd = 15.88)
155/200 for final (mean = 125.33, sd = 30.03)
Then, I get a A- grade.

You should expect all student will get almost full mark for assignment and project cause it is very easy to do and you can use a 'coupon' to waive a question in the homework.
reviews.comment_workload:
Relatively light when comparing to other 3 cred course.
All assignment and project are very easy to do, you just need to follow the instruction or lecture note. If you have the source from previous semesters, you can find that some question in the homework are the same and you can just copy it from the source.

reviews.author: USTAsiaNo.0
reviews.title: Overrated
reviews.comment_content:
Content taught is still manageable (PS im a business student), will have advantages if you're in CS I guess.
The professor put a lot of emphasis on your math skills, a large portion of the exam paper is based on mathematical knowledge e.g. probability and complex equations.
I guess in order to master this course, mathematical skills is more important than technical CS knowledge..
reviews.comment_teaching: Raymond is a passionate professor without doubt. Erm, but I have to be honest, I find his ppt quite unorganized and a bit hard to follow.
reviews.comment_grading:
OVERRATED!! 伏!!!!!
Don't understand why the means of this semester are much lower than the previous ones, but the grading is much worse... -,-
The final for this year is also much tougher, we got the same number of questions as before but 0.5 hour less... =,=
Saw that b+ is the mean grade in previous semesters, and above mean 0.7sd in the final could already guarantee an A-?????
That's BS, I got above mean 0.4 sd in final, mid term mean, project, assignments and participation all full mark but end up with just a B...
If I had known about the grading scheme, I wouldn't have taken this course as a business student... -,-
reviews.comment_workload:
Just a group project and 2 assignments, will be easy if you have sources (and smart friends lmao)
But I have to be honest, you have to do a lot of work after class in order to catch up

reviews.author: 清水灣廢青
reviews.title: Raymond Wong has changed!
reviews.comment_content:
6 Main Topics:
1. Association: Apriori, FP growth
2. Clustering: k-Means, hierarchical
3. Classification: Decision Tree, Naive Bayes, k-Nearest Neighbor, Neural Network, concepts like true positive, accuracy, etc.
4. Data Warehouse
5. Dimension Reduction (Principal Component Analysis)
6. Wed Databases
You should obtain 3 coupons to waive 2 hw and the project output (once you use the coupon on output file, you will automatically obtain 20% even without submitting the file).
By the way, the final is quite different from previous years.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is extremely good. Raymond is funny and very well-prepared in every lecture as he is very clear about the goal of each lecture. Email is very detailed and well-explained. But there is a local accent.
reviews.comment_grading:
I would say it was overrated in the past. If your goal is getting B/B+, this is the class for you because it is every easy to obtain B/B+. If your goal is getting A/A+, this is not the class for you.
For me, I got full marks in all HW/Projects/Participation(I guess most of the students also did it). Mid terms (20%): 75/100 (mean 65.78/100) above 0.5sd. Final (40%) 165/200 (mean~125) above more than 1.3 sd. Overall getting above 1 sd (i guess). But still obtain an A-.
Actually, I am very disappointed to the current grade.
reviews.comment_workload: little bit too heavy actually. There are two assignments which contain 5 questions each. Some of them are time-consuming. However, if you have source, it is okay. For the project, the workload is quite heavy if you do it seriously. As you do not know how they grade your project, it is likely you will spend a whole day on it.

reviews.author: I.048S96
reviews.title: Best Course So Far. Deserves a Teaching Excellence Award.
reviews.comment_content:
The contents include:

1) Association
2) Cluster (k-Means, Dendogram)
3) Classification (Decision Tree, Naive Bayes, NN Classifier, Neural Network)
4) PCA
5) Data Warehouse
6) Web DB

The content is extremely fruitful so you may have a difficult time studying for your finals, but still it is a great course. The concept itself may feel difficult at first, but if you listen to the lectures, the professor makes the course material understandable (which you don't see too much often here at HKUST).
reviews.comment_teaching:
Best teaching at HKUST so far. He is a very passionate lecturer; he is willing to embrace all students who cannot follow along with the course pace. He is very open to questions, so if you email him about any question, he will respond extremely quickly. (BTW I don't think he sleeps early. His emails come at like 1,2 am in the morning)

There are some math involved in the course and because he knows most students cannot follow, he slows down and explains the same thing many times. (Especially at the first few lectures in association rule, he will repeat the calculation like four times. But later he will speed things up a little bit...)

Some people might find his accent/pronunciation funny. He pronounces "sheet" in a very concise way, and he uses the word "coupon" a lot and it sounds like "Q-pon".
reviews.comment_grading:
Just like any COMP classes, the grading is very objective. If you deserve 100, the professor and TAs will give you a 100.

I suggest that when you get your assignment scores, project scores, exam scores, you should take a look and talk to the professor if you think you deserve more points. The professor is open to changing scores if you deserve more (and if you can elaborate your answers).

Project: 100/100
Midterm: 97/100 (was 94)
Final: 195/200 (was 189)
Participation: 10/10
Assignment 1: 10/10 (was 9.5)
Assignment 2: 9.6/10 (was 9.0)

I don't know what my letter grade is yet but probably many other students have high scores as well.

The mean scores are:
Project: 90.79/100 (SD: 19.90)
Midterm: 69.49/100 (SD: 17.12)
Final: 151.57/200 (SD: 36.63)

The rest I don't know. He will probably provide those numbers if you email him.
reviews.comment_workload:
Not too much.

There is a participation score but you just need to have 20 units of iPRS questions, which is easy to get. You don't have to go to every single lecture. Some lectures have 3 iPRS questions so by the end of the term, there is no need to go to the lectures. You can watch the video link provided by the department (which is actually better) when studying for the exams/assignments.

Assignments are short, you can waive one question with a Q-pon. You get a Q-pon by answering questions during the lecture. You will need about 4 to go through the semester (1 per assignment/project). I ended up gathering five in the first two weeks and didn't participate after then.

There is a project but... I don't think the grading is very harsh. Didn't expect the mean to be as high as 90.79 but it's not very difficult, just do what he teaches you in the lectures (takes about 4~6 hours I guess if you do it alone).

reviews.author: chloeB
reviews.comment_content: this class is about data classification and correlation finding. It's useful but seems kinda old considering even isom2500 has already talked about using python to categorizing data.
reviews.comment_teaching: Raymond is a rl nice and patient teacher(his accent is quite heavy though: ) and he has been trying this class interesting. Also he welcomes you to ask him questions.
reviews.comment_grading: Midterm and final actually takes large share in grading while they r kinda hard and the questions r somehow different from practise we did on class.
reviews.comment_workload: I think it's reasonable. Not too heavy nor light but enough for you to practice and bearable. 3 real small projects 2 hw, 1 midterm and  final.

reviews.author: Argen
reviews.title: Never regret for taking this course
reviews.comment_content:
The course teaches ways to find some interesting relationship in a database. XLMiner is used as the assistant software.
Topics include:

Association Rule Mining
- Apriori
- FP tree
Clustering
- (forgetful) (sequential) k-means
Classification
- Decision Tree
- Naive Bayes
- Nearest Neighbour
- Neural network
Data Warehouse
PCA
Web Database (Search Engine)

Most of the topics are the algorithm used in handling data. And we have to learn the concepts and procedures of these algorithms.
However, as a common core, the course only provides BASIC information on how the above approaches work, and the examples used are not comprehensive though.
It is a good choice for you if you are quite interested in data mining and DO NOT WANT TO CODE.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Raymond is a dedicated lecturer. He explains everything clearly and step-by-step. He is democratic that all formats (length, type of questions, difficulty of questions, etc) of midterm and final exam are voted by students.

His lecture is interactive, students are welcomed and highly encouraged to answer his question. By answering his question correctly, you will be awarded a coupon that allows you to waive one question in assignment/project (and obtain full mark for that question)

He always sends emails to further explain some frequently asked topics or questions. And finally, his efficiency and speed of release of grades are insane :P.
(My final exam finished at 7:30pm and the mark was sent to me at 1am.)
That's all.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good grade. Even better than heated COMP courses like COMP1021 and COMP1022Q.

mean = B+ ~ A-
I have friends who are below mean in both midterm and final exam but get B+.

Midterm 20%
Final 40%
HW 10%
Project 20%
Participation (iPRS) 10%

It is easy to get the full mark in HW, project and participation.
For participation, you just need to answer 25 iPRS questions out of over 60 over the semester, no need to be correct.
reviews.comment_workload:
Appropriate.
2 assignments (5 questions each) for the whole semester.
1 project (1-2 people a group) with 3 phases.
I spent 10 mins on phase 1, and 2 hours on phase 2 and 3 each.

"Source" is quite important for this course. You can spend much less time and effort to complete to tasks if you have the solution of past paper and exercises.

reviews.author: iwantarange
reviews.title: Very good introduction to data mining
reviews.comment_content:
An elementary level course on data mining. Topics included:
1. Association: Apriori, FP growth
2. Clustering: k-Means, hierarchical
3. Classification: Decision Tree, Naive Bayes, k-Nearest Neighbor, Neural Network, concepts like true positive, accuracy, etc.
4. Data Warehouse
5. Dimension Reduction (Principal Component Analysis)
6. Wed Databases

The difficulty of most contents are well-selected to be a common core level. You may feel it is a bit easy if you have a solid background on math or computer science. There are some topics that you may have not learned before (for example, basic matrix operation), but those will be covered in the tutorials.

Using XLMiner in Excel is one of the highlights of this course. It is a tool for you to perform data mining in Excel. Some tutorials may be used to teach the way to use XLMiner. Raymond may also mention it himself during lectures.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Raymond explains things quite clearly, and he is willing to answer any questions regarding the content of the course. He is probably famous for replying emails with a fast speed. In addition to that, his replies are clear and rich in content. Just read other course reviews to see how nice he is.

I didn't attend any tutorials not about XLMiner, so I cannot give any review on that. For those tutorials about XLMiner, the TA goes through the steps of doing different data mining techniques slowly. This may be helpful if you can't really understand the procedures or you are lazy to learn it yourself.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading Scheme:
Assignment x2 10% (easy to obtain high score)
Project 20% (easy to obtain high score)
In-class Participation 10% (iPRS)
Midterm 20% (Mean: 65.76/100, SD: 15.88, Max: 98)
Final 40% (Mean: 125.33/200, SD: 30.03, Max: 196.25)

Get coupons by answering questions during lectures. These coupons can allow you to waive a part of the assignments and project and guarantees a full score. Raymond will even "force" you to obtain some coupons at a later stage of the course, so it should be easy to obtain them.

Getting a course total of 96.7% yields an A+. It is lucky to have an A+, but probably due to the significant increase of difficulty in the final exam. Your score is especially outstanding if you perform well in the final exam. A reminder for anyone taking this course: the time for exams this year are quite insufficient, so try to rush over the questions.
reviews.comment_workload:
Assignments: I do not have "sources", and it spends me about 3~5 hours for both. Some questions ask you to use XLMiner, so that may waste you a bit of time.

Project: Not sure if I treat it too seriously, but the workload is not as light as other people suggested. Phase 1 is easy for everyone and it does not cause you more than 30 minutes. Phase 2 is the design report. Mine contains 14 pages including screenshots from XLMiner, which causes me at least 5 hours. Phase 3 is the final report, which can be based on the design report. Mine contains 21 pages including screenshots from XLMiner, which causes me 8~10 hours.

reviews.author: qjk
reviews.title: [伏中之伏] How to become a human computer 101
reviews.comment_content:
You will learn some common data mining techniques and algorithms.

However, this is not a math course. So, you won't be learning about the mathematical principles behind these algorithms.

This isn't a coding course either. So, you won't be learning how to implement these algorithms in code.

What else is left to learn? How to "run" these algorithms by hand! Sounds fun? You will be performing repetitive, mechanical calculations by hand to solve problems that would take a computer 0.01 milliseconds to solve.

If you can write code to solve these problems, however, you can own those SBM noobs who can't code, and laugh as they take 30 minutes to solve a problem on the final that took you 1 second to solve, cos you wrote a program for it.
reviews.comment_teaching:
In terms of teaching, Raymond has a lot of room for improvement. However, he is nice and gave me a good grade, so I will give a C here instead of E.

Raymond is really nice and will answer your emails promptly. The teaching team is also efficient and finishes marking exams/assignments in 1-2 days.

However, Raymond is really terrible as a teacher.

Raymond forces you to attend nearly every lesson. You need to submit screenshots of your Zoom attendance 15 times and answer 20 IPRS questions. At 1 IPRS per lecture, you can only miss 3 or 4 lectures.

Attending Raymond's lectures is actively detrimental to my learning progress. Once in a while, some disruptive students will ask some stupid questions and he will go out of his way to answer them. Literally, 90% of the questions raised in lectures were asked by the same single student. However, Raymond is too nice to tell him to just SHUT UP.

Raymond also has a  coupon system where you get a coupon if you answer a question in class which you can use to get full marks on a homework question. Raymond wants to give every student a chance to answer a question in class, so he goes out of his way to ask a lot of trivial questions. Interactiveness is good but Raymond is really taking it overboard to the point that it is disrupting the flow of the lecture.

Moreover, Raymond talks so slowly that I drift off and lose focus every 10 seconds. If you are an individual of higher intelligence whose brain operates on a higher frequency and therefore prefers watching lecture videos at 2x speed, too bad! Raymond forces you to attend his lectures.

Furthermore, Raymond has a fetish with long documents. His powerpoints will make you want to rip your eyes out. They are usually 100 slides long. He likes to animate his powerpoints FRAME BY FRAME. 80% of the slides in his powerpoints do not contain useful information. Moreover, your project report will be around 50 pages long, mostly consisting of screenshots detailing how you use the data mining tool. Therefore, you will spend more time furiously flicking your mouse scroll wheel to navigate the document instead of actually typing stuff.

You would think a CSE professor would be more tech-savvy. While UST's LANG courses are completely useless to us undergraduates, I think Raymond will really benefit from attending a LANG course to upgrade his presentation skills.
reviews.comment_grading:
In terms of grading, this course gets an F for fascism.

Example from the final exam:
Q: Is it possible to find X? If yes, what is X? If no, explain.
A: X = 3.

Wrong! -1 point, "missing answer to yes/no question"

Welcome to North Korea!

The exam format was highly inconsistent. The midterm was 50/50 LQ MC with NO mechanical questions that you can write programs for, while the final was 100% LQ with 2 questions worth 40% of the total solvable within 1 second with pre-written code. The midterm got me good and I barely got 50%, but luckily I had a good comeback in the final. Personally, I do not appreciate this kind of inconsistency in exam format, as students can not adequately prepare for the exam by doing past papers. This is another reason this course sucks. You never know what Raymond is going to throw at you next time.

Statistics:
10% HW Full
10% Attendance Should be Full
20% Project nearly full
20% + 40% Midterms and Finals +0.9 SD averaged
->A-

Luckily, the final is worth twice as much as the midterm, so you can make a comeback if you screw up in your midterm.

Raymond lets us vote on the format of the exams. For the midterm, some naive kids voted for 50% Long Q 50% MC.
As a result, the midterm was very fun. MC is very fun because it's all-or-nothing, no partial credit. I only got 3/10 of the MC.

Raymond also removed all MC questions from the past paper. Maybe he is too lazy to design new MC questions and reuse them every year. Too bad if you want to do past papers to prepare for the MC part!

Finals were 100% Long Q. 10 questions 20 marks each. 2 questions can be solved with code right off the bat, so 40 marks there. For the rest, most were copied from the past papers. Raymond didn't even bother changing the numbers for one question, so I just copy-pasted the solution from a past paper. (It was open book)
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is pretty huge.

If you want A range, you must do at least 5 or 6 past papers, and write code for every single question type. I think there are several question types but each type has a couple variations, so you will need to write a few dozen programs in total.

Raymond sets the deadline for homeworks and project reports at 10:30 in the morning. If you are someone who cannot focus on a homework assignment unless the deadline is less than 6 hours away, your sleep schedule will suffer.

The homeworks are time-consuming, and you need to triple-check your answers. The project report is also tedious. You need to use the data mining tool and paste screenshots of every step, i.e., every button you click.

Projects requirements were not clearly communicated. The TAs will even penalize minor formatting mistakes. If your solution isn't a carbon copy of the official solution, you will get points deducted.
